html:
• anchor

    Photo: © Ossip van Duivenbode

    MVRDV’s longstanding relationship with its home city of Rotterdam will usher in a new chapter this week with the opening of the new Portlantis visitors center and exhibition space for the Port of Rotterdam.

    Appearing as a stack of five rotated volumes, the upper half of the building's program entails a top-floor restaurant with operable windows and a fourth-floor exhibition gallery dedicated to the port’s future adaptation to Paris Agreement benchmarks, topped by an accessible rooftop that culminates the journey for users with vistas of the city, dunes, and port terminals below.

    The lower half begins with a ground floor café framed by a dramatic 72-foot unifying atrium. From there, visitors will emerge into the first of three exhibition floors focused on the port’s operations, local environmental and economic impact, constituent role in global trade, and influence over the daily lives of Rotterdamers.

    Color plays an important role in the building’s wayfinding strategy and spatial experience, with red being used in its external stair, an exposed orange ventilation pipe running through the first floor, and yellow kinetic sculptural elements suspended above the atrium in order to define it as the vertical "heart" of the design.

    MVRDV founder Winy Maas says: "Portlantis is a beacon, it’s eye-catching, but it’s also a kind of watchtower. [It] gives people a way to investigate, to see how things are changing in the port, how that relates to the city, and how it affects the life they live in the city. It does this extremely efficiently – like a machine for storytelling."

    The structure is demountable with the façade panels to be returned at the end of their lifespan under an agreement made with the manufacturer. It also generates 30% more energy than it uses locally thanks to the incorporation of an on-site windmill, according to the firm.

    Portlantis is located on Maasvlakte 2 artificial island and follows the completion of the Depot Boijmans Van Beuningen visible art storage facility in Rotterdam in 2021.
